message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with painless rectal bleeding, an uncomfortable lump when defecating, and bright red blood on the examination glove. These symptoms suggest internal hemorrhoids, which are located above the pectinate line. Grades 1 and 2 external hemorrhoids are located below the pectinate line, while Grade 3 external hemorrhoids involve prolapse of the hemorrhoidal tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest internal hemorrhoids, specifically Grade 2 internal hemorrhoids as they may protrude outside the anus during defecation but will spontaneously reduce afterwards. Grade 1 external hemorrhoids would not be seen on anoscopy while Grade 2 and 3 external hemorrhoids would be located below the pectinate line.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest internal hemorrhoids, which are located above the pectinate line. Grade 1 external hemorrhoids do not involve bleeding, while Grade 2 and Grade 3 external hemorrhoids involve bleeding with or without prolapse of the hemorrhoids, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of painless rectal bleeding and an uncomfortable lump in his anus, which are characteristic of internal hemorrhoids. Anoscopy confirms enlarged blood vessels above the pectinate line, which is consistent with grade 2 internal hemorrhoids. Grade 1 and 2 external hemorrhoids present with itching and anal discomfort, while grade 3 external hemorrhoids present with prolapse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that there is bright red blood on the glove after the digital rectal exam indicates the bleeding is coming from higher up in the rectum (above the pectinate line), which rules out external hemorrhoids (grades 1-3) since they are below this line. The presentation is consistent with Grade 2 internal hemorrhoids, which can cause bleeding and a feeling of an uncomfortable lump during defecation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of intermittent streaks of bright red blood on toilet paper and blood on, but not mixed within, the stool suggests internal hemorrhoids. The uncomfortable lump in the anus could be an internal hemorrhoid prolapsing, which is consistent with grade 2 internal hemorrhoids. Grades 1 and 2 external hemorrhoids are not typically associated with rectal bleeding. Grade 3 external hemorrhoids usually cause significant pain and bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of painless rectal bleeding and an uncomfortable lump suggest internal hemorrhoids, and the enlarged blood vessels seen on anoscopy support this diagnosis. The bleeding is described as intermittent and not associated with the passage of stool, which is typical of internal hemorrhoids above the pectinate line. The grading system for internal hemorrhoids is different from that for external hemorrhoids, and grade 2 internal hemorrhoids are defined as protruding hemorrhoids that require manual reduction. Neither the external hemorrhoids nor the grade 1 category involves internal protrusion, and grade 3 external hemorrhoids are defined as prolapsing hemorrhoids that require manual reduction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, examination findings, and location of enlarged blood vessels suggest the most likely cause is Grade 2 internal hemorrhoids. Grade 1 external hemorrhoids do not prolapse, Grade 2 external hemorrhoids prolapse but reduce spontaneously, and Grade 3 external hemorrhoids prolapse and require manual reduction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intermittent streaks of bright red blood on the toilet paper and blood on but not mixed within the stool suggest internal hemorrhoids. The uncomfortable lump in the anus may be a prolapsed internal hemorrhoid. Anoscopy shows enlarged blood vessels above the pectinate line, which is consistent with Grade 2 internal hemorrhoids. Grade 1 external hemorrhoids do not prolapse, Grade 2 external hemorrhoids prolapse with defecation but reduce spontaneously, and Grade 3 external hemorrhoids prolapse with defecation but require manual reduction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including bright red blood on the toilet paper, blood on the surface of the stool, and an uncomfortable lump, suggest internal hemorrhoids. Anoscopy shows enlarged blood vessels above the pectinate line, which is consistent with Grade 2 internal hemorrhoids. Grade 1 external hemorrhoids do not present with a lump, while Grades 2 and 3 external hemorrhoids present with a lump that can be manually reduced.
